root.publications: Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.

child.publications: Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.

child.pub-comments: Author notes that his Central Miao and Western Miao groups are included in the group that the Chinese Institute of National Languages (1962) calls Ch'uan-ch'ien-tien (Purnell 1970:39).
child.publications: Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.
Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.
Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.

child.pub-comments: Author notes that Ma Hsueh-liang (1957) calls this same group "Central Miao" and the Chinese Institute of National Languages (1962) calls it Ch'ien-tung (Purnell 1970:39).
child.publications: Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.

child.pub-comments: Author notes that Ma Hsueh-liang (1957) calls this same group "Eastern Miao" and the Chinese Institute of National Languages (1962) calls it Hsiang-hsi (Purnell 1970:39).
child.publications: Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.

child.pub-comments: "Hua-yuan is actually a composite of two virtually identical Miao dialects, both spoken in Hua-yuan: Chi-wei and La-yi-p'ing" (Purnell 1970:20). "Although Hua-yuan was referred to above as a "Northern Miao" dialect, the fact that it is the only type of "Northern Miao" represented here necessitates its being derived directly from Proto-Miao (Purnell 1970:91).
child.publications: Purnell, Herbert. 1970. Toward a Reconstruction of Proto-Miao-Yao.
